snippet: Citing a variety of reasons, the N.F.L. players union is seeking to void Roger Goodell’s suspensions of four players linked to the Saints’ bounty program.
abstract: NFL players union files grievance seeking to void NFL commissioner Roger Goodell's suspensions of four players linked the the New York Saints bounty program. (M)
lead_paragraph: In the first move of what figures to be a contentious fight, the N.F.L. players union launched its defense of four New Orleans Saints players suspended for their roles in the team's bounty program with a three-pronged attack on Commissioner Roger Goodell's authority. The union filed a grievance Thursday night arguing that broad language contained in the collective bargaining agreement prohibits Goodell from disciplining players for conduct committed before Aug. 4, 2011, the day the C.B.A. was signed. That would eliminate the first two years of the three-year bounty program that the N.F.L. contends was run in New Orleans, including some of the most troublesome allegations -- that the defensive captain Jonathan Vilma offered $10,000 if hits knocked Brett Favre and Kurt Warner out of playoff games in 2010.

headline.main: Union Files Grievance Over Bounty Suspensions
